Part of Speech: adverb
Definition: while
Derivative: dum

Part of Speech: adverb
Definition: because of, on account of
Derivative: propter

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: to the individual person
“The gladiator swung ad hominem attacks on me before we battled—he said he didn’t like the haircut I just got from a barber in Trajan’s Forum!”
Derivative:

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: according to value
“I calculated my ad valorem tax after I bought my new house— it was definitely according to value.”
Derivative: according to value

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: to nausea
“The presenter spoke about his graphs ad nauseam—we were nearly bored to death!”
Derivative: ad nauseam

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: from the fact
“Although English is the de facto primary language taught in schools today, we believe Latin should be!”
Derivative: de facto

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: and other things
“My grocery list includes bananas, fruit cups, cheese, sweet potatoes, cranberry juice, collard greens, et cetera—if I named the entire list, it would take up an entire page!”
Derivative: et cetera

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: way of living
“My sister’s modus vivendi is so care-free that I’m surprised she decided to major in mathematics in college—she won’t have any free time now!”
Derivative: modus vivendi

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: by himself/itself
“Nerva wasn’t necessarily a great emperor per se—he just seemed great in comparison to his predecessor, the horrible Domitian!”
Derivative: per se

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: by head
“Apples are the number one fruit consumed per capita in the United States—I can count at least 20 people on my block who eat them daily!”
Derivative: per capita

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: by the day
“We asked our parents for a per diem allowance, to which they responded, “Do your daily chores and maybe we’ll agree to this!”
Derivative: per diem

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: something for someone
“The cleaner wrasse fish negotiated a quid pro quo with the shark—“I’ll clean your teeth in exchange for you not eating me!”
Derivative: quid pro quo

Part of Speech: phrase
Definition: the situation in which
“Our town’s government maintained the status quo by not proposing new ideas. On account of its stagnancy, I decided to relocate to a more progressive city.”
Derivative:
